page.title: 03LAUND HOUSE FARM CONTINUED
page.content: At present there are four hundred beef cattle kept in outbuildings at the farm. Normally they are kept outside in the fields until there is no grazing left, but this year, due to heavy rain, the ground is very wet, and the animals were making the fields very messy, so it was decided to move them inside. While inside, they are being fed this year on potatoes and barley. The reason for potatoes being used as fodder is that this year they have been overproduced and their price is very low. There are two untarred roads leading to the farm. One runs east and joins a narrow tarred road. The other runs south-west, going through two other farms. One of these is also called Laund House, the other called Hull Bank. The second road eventually joins the A19 north of Skipton.
